metadata.synopsis: In 1979 Ohio, several youngsters (Elle Fanning, Joel Courtney, Gabriel Basso) are making a zombie movie with a Super-8 camera. In the midst of filming, the friends witness a horrifying train derailment and are lucky to escape with their lives. They soon discover that the catastrophe was no accident, as a series of unexplained events and disappearances soon follows. Deputy Jackson Lamb (Kyle Chandler), the father of one of the kids, searches for the terrifying truth behind the crash.

reviews: It's a by-the-numbers blockbuster, but one with a key element that's missing from most of the big-budget bloatfests crowding each other for space on the marquee every summer: heart.
Takes a winning formula and replicates it to a successful degree - but very little originality finds its way into the film.
A film that manages to remind us that the scariest monster flicks are those where we actually care about those who are involved.
Super 8 is a bit of a frustrating movie. It's well-paced, emotional, and captures a certain innocence of pre-pubescent youth, without becoming too cheesy.
Abrams seems more concerned with emulating the Spielbergian way than mining the true emotion that can be felt.
Feels more like a faded memory than a movie.
This might not be the most original piece of work, but it's one of those films that show that sometimes familiar can be a good thing.
Super 8 is pretty much awash in charm.
The kids are the true stars here.
Yet Super 8, which was co-produced by Spielberg, is not so much an homage to a master, but a counterfeit copy of one of his originals.
The trouble is that the answer awaiting at the end of Super 8 simply isn't very satisfying. But don't let that put you off, because the journey to get to this disappointment is a rewarding one.
The film is covered in a thick syrup of nostalgia that often threatens to choke the life out of it.
It's impossible not to get caught up in Abrams' nostalgia for summer days at the Cineplex gone by.
Those stupid interminable close-ups of Dee Wallace-Stone's suburban-mom face, upturned and simpering-will I ever be able to scrub them from my memory?
No it's not a masterpiece - but it's a solid little movie, and I'd highly recommend it.
The movie doesn't have all the elements necessary to make it a true classic, but there are some admirable things it accomplishes, especially when the enthusiastic kids are at the forefront.
No film this year opens more promisingly and ends more dismally than J.J. Abrams' Super 8.
I really enjoyed Super 8. Kind of loved it, even.
Like Silly Putty, Super 8 is silly fun. It stretches, snaps, and bounces. It's as elastic as pubescent imagination.
An idealistic and powerful summer film with great characters and a wonderful script.
